IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
Driver: Amir Hesam Etesam
MD OLN: MD10272270642
DUI #: 23-010
Video: W-8 is equipped with mobile recording equipment. My agency issued body cam remained activated throughout the incident.
Subsequent Offender:  No

VEHICLE IN MOTION:
                On 2/24/2023 at approximately 2340 hours, I, TFC. Bradley was operating my marked patrol vehicle (W-8) on S/B U.S. Rt. 219 near Gravelly Run Rd behind a dark colored SUV and a white passenger vehicle. The SUV was directly in front of me and the white passenger vehicle was in front of the SUV. As I followed the vehicles, I observed the white Toyota swerving back and forth within the travel lane. I then activated W-8’s front facing camera to document the vehicle’s operation. As we passed Lake Shore Drive, I observed the left side tires of the Toyota travel directly on top of the yellow center lines for approximately 50 feet before correcting. We continued South on Rt. 219 as I observed the white Toyota repeatedly cross the white fog line and enter the shoulder area by more than one tire width. As we approached Glendale Rd, I again observed the Toyota’s left side tires cross the yellow center lines and drive for approximately 50 feet with the tires to the left of the center lines. Both vehicles turned left on Glendale Road as I continued behind them. As we drove on Glendale Road, I continued to observe the white Toyota swerve left to right within his travel lane. As we approached Glen Acres Drive, I activated my emergency equipment and conducted a traffic stop on the Toyota.

PERSONAL CONTACT:
                I made contact with the driver of the white Toyota via driver’s door approach and immediately detected the strong odor of alcoholic beverage emanating from the interior of the vehicle. I observed the driver’s eyes to appear bloodshot and glassy as I introduced myself and advised the driver the reason for the traffic stop. The driver apologized and stated, “I didn’t see that you had the siren on, I was talking to my girlfriend.” I asked him for his driver’s license and registration card. The driver provided me with his driver’s license and he was identified as Amir Hesam Etesam. I asked him how many drinks he consumed that night, he replied, “none.” I asked him where he was coming from, he advised he was coming from Rockville for vacation. Etesam sorted through paperwork for approximately one minute before providing me with the registration card for the vehicle. I returned to my patrol vehicle before returning to the Toyota and asking Etesam to exit the vehicle and perform field sobriety tests, he agreed.  

PRE-ARREST SCREENING:
                The evaluation was performed in front of my patrol vehicle, using the shoulder area of Glendale Road and Glen Acres Drive. The area was dry, flat and free of debris. The weather was clear and approximately 25 degrees Fahrenheit. Lighting conditions consisted of my flashlight and vehicle headlamps. Etesam appeared to be in good physical condition and did not display any physical injuries, limps or limb ailments. Etesam’s back was faced towards traffic and my patrol vehicle. The front emergency lights were deactivated in my patrol vehicle. I asked Etesam the following questions:
How many drinks consumed before driving: None.
Where are you coming from right now: Brother’s residence on Ski Drive.
Medications: Bupropon.
Physical medical disabilities: No.
Recent Injuries: No.
Glasses or contacts: No.
        As I made contact with Etesam outside of his vehicle, I continued to detect the strong odor of alcoholic beverage emanating from his breath and person and observed his eyes to appear bloodshot and glassy.

HORIZONTAL GAZE NYSTAGMUS (HGN) TEST (4/6 CLUES OBSERVED)
        The first test given was the Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus test. Etesam was turned so that his back was towards my patrol vehicle and traffic. My black ballpoint pen was used as the test stimulus and held approximately 12 inches from Etesam’s eyes. Etesam was instructed to look straight ahead, keeping his head still while following and focusing on the stimulus with his eyes only until told to stop. Etesam’s pupils were equal in size and showed equal tracking. Etesam advised he understood the instructions.
  1. Etesam displayed lack of smooth pursuit in both eyes.
  2. Etesam displayed distinct and sustained nystagmus at maximum deviation in both eyes.
  3. Etesam did not display the onset of nystagmus prior to 45 degrees in both eyes.
*Etesam did not display vertical nystagmus.

WALK AND TURN TEST (5/8 CLUES OBSERVED)
                Prior to Etesam performing the test, I properly explained and demonstrated how the test was to be conducted. Etesam was instructed to place his right foot in front of his left and touch heel to toe. Etesam was instructed to place his hands at his side and to remain in that position until told otherwise. I asked Etesam if he understood, he advised he did. Etesam was advised to take nine (9) steps straight out in front of him, touching heel to toe on every step. He was to keep his hands down at his side, keep his eyes focused on his feet, and to count every step aloud. On the ninth step Etesam was demonstrated and explained to keep his lead foot planted and to take a series of small steps around with his rear foot to turn completely around without stopping. Etesam was again explained and demonstrated the second series of steps to be performed identical to the first series. Etesam was advised once he started the test, he was not to stop until the test was completely finished. After explaining and demonstrating the test, I asked Etesam if he understood the instructions, he replied he did.
Instructional Stage:
  1. Etesam lost balance and broke the instructional stage position twice.
First Nine:
  1. Etesam stepped off line on step 3 of the first nine steps, needing to take an additional step to regain balance.
  2. Etesam raised his arms during the first nine steps.
The Turn:
  1. Etesam took the final step of the first nine steps, stopped and asked how to complete the turn. He then pivoted on both feet to turn around, contrary to instruction.
Second Nine:
  1. Etesam stepped off line on step 4 of the second nine steps.
  2. Etesam raised his arms during the second nine steps.
  3. Etesam counted “one,” after completing the turn but did not take his first step yet. He took eight actual steps opposed to nine as instructed.  
Before proceeding with the screening, I asked Etesam why he could not put his feet completely together since he didn’t advise me of any injuries or disabilities before the testing. He told me he was born with his knees bowed, not allowing his feet to be that close to each other.

ONE-LEG STAND TEST (3/4 CLUES OBSERVED)
                Prior to Etesam performing the test, I properly explained and demonstrated how the test should be conducted. Etesam was instructed to stand with his feet together and hands down to his sides while the instructions were given and during the test. Etesam was instructed not to begin the test until he was instructed to start, and after the test had been demonstrated. When instructed to start, he was to raise the foot of his choice off the ground approximately six (6) inches. While his leg was raised, he was to keep his leg straight, keep his toe pointed forward, watch his raised foot, and to count out loud by thousands (one thousand one, one thousand two, one thousand three...) and to continue the test until told to stop (30 seconds). Etesam advised that he understood all the instructions. He balanced on his right leg with his left leg raised.
Seconds 0-10:
  1. Etesam raised his arms during the first ten seconds of the test.
Seconds 11-20:
  1. Etesam swayed during the second ten seconds.
  2. Etesam hopped during the second ten seconds.
Seconds 21-30:
  1. Etesam raised his arms during the third ten seconds.
  2. Etesam swayed during the third ten seconds.
  3. Etesam hopped during the third ten seconds.

COUNT BACKWARDS:
                Etesam agreed to count backwards from 59 to 36.
  • Nothing to report.
PRELIMINARY BREATH TEST (PBT):
                Etesam refused to submit to a PBT at approximately 0001 hours.

ARREST/DR-15 ADVICE OF RIGHTS:
                Due to the facts above, Etesam was placed under arrest for driving under the influence of alcohol at approximately 0001 hours. Etesam’s girlfriend (Fahima Ashoory) agreed to a PBT with results of .000 grams of alcohol per 210 milliliters of breath. Etesam requested she take possession of his vehicle. Etesam was transported to the McHenry barrack for processing. Etesam was read his DR-15 Advice of Rights and provided with a physical copy of the DR-15 Advice of Rights to read along with. At approximately 0028 hours, Etesam agreed to submit to a breath test. I check Etesam’s mouth for any foreign objects and none were discovered at approximately 0036 hours.

INTOXIMETER RESULT:
                The breath test was administered by Cpl. Arnold #4752 at approximately 0057 hours. One sufficient sample of Etesam’s breath was obtained before the test was canceled from mouth alcohol detection. Etesam was allowed to use the restroom at this time and the observation time restarted at approximately 0105 hours. The breath test was again administered by Cpl. Arnold at approximately 0129 hours. Two (2) sufficient samples of Etesam’s breath were obtained. The breath specimen was found to contain an alcohol concentration of 0.04 grams of alcohol per 210 liters of breath.
                Etesam was processed, provided with his copies of paperwork, advised not to drive for 12 hours and released to Ashoory from the McHenry Barrack. As I made contact with Etesam throughout the morning, I continued to detect the odor of alcoholic beverage emanating from his breath and person and observed his eyes to be bloodshot and glassy.

Case closed by arrest.

All above events occurred in Garrett County, Maryland.
